Dear Ms. Quintana-Montenegro:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on March
11, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include
the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis
Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial

agency, or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually resides,
that the person has not been determined
to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be
completed not more than 30 days prior to
the start of employment and every 12
months thereafter.
Nine of fourteen new employee files did not meet the requirements of the rule as
they did not have a central registry clearance completed within 30 days prior to
hire. The facility utilizes the CWL-4624 to check confirmed cases as well as
central registry for new staff. Eight new employees had a CWL-4624 completed
over 30 days prior to their hire date. One new employee had a CWL-4624
completed 4 days after his hire date.
One of six employees hired over 12 months did not have a central registry
clearance completed annually as required. The employee's last CR was
completed in 2022.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained
prior to employment from persons unrelated to
the employee and which are less than 12
months old.
One of fourteen new employees did not have three references completed within
12 months prior to hire. The employee was hired on 9/25/23 and his references
were dated 3/2/22.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers
(1) The licensee shall document, prior to
employment, that each employee and volunteer
who has contact with residents 4 or more hours
per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is
free from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom
from communicable tuberculosis shall be verified
within the 1 year period before employment and
shall be verified every 1 year after the last

verification or prior to the expiration of the
current verification.
One of fourteen new employees did not have a TB test completed prior to hire.
CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written
health service policies and procedures
addressing all of the following:
(d) Storage of medications.
During the on-site visit at the facility on 3/11/24, the medication cart was not
locked per facility policy. The staff office the medication cart is located in was
locked.
CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of
restraints.
(1) A child caring institution, including private secure
juvenile justice facilities, shall establish a
process improvement and restraint
reduction/elimination plan that:
(d) Staff must complete refresher training
annually or more frequently as needed.
Two of six employees hired over 12 months did not complete restraint training
annually as required. One employee was hired on 6/22/22 and never completed
the full CPI training. He completed a blended refresher CPI training on 11/2/23,
which is over a year after his hire date. One employee was hired on 8/21/19 and
completed CPI training on 3/5/20. However, she did not complete another CPI
training until 10/5/23 when she completed the refresher course.
CCI Rule 400.4167 Case record maintenance
(1) The insitution shall maintain a case record for
each resident.
(2) Service plans shall be signed and dated by the
social services worker and the social services
supervisor.
One of eight closed youth files reviewed did not contain any service plans.
Two of eight closed youth files reviewed did not have supervisor signatures on all
service plans.

CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days
after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and
the new location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of
the services provided while in residence,
including medical and dental services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that
remain to be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the
facility after discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and
dental follow up that is needed, have been
reviewed with the resident and with the
parent and with the responsible case
manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to
whom the resident was discharged.
Two of eight closed youth files did not contain a discharge report.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The facility has stated more than once the reasons for some non-compliances
are because they are meeting ORR requirements, but not considering licensing
requirements. To maintain licensing for this facility under the State of Michigan,
licensing rules must be followed regardless of any contractor requirements.
• Variance requests must be submitted and approved prior to hiring or promoting a
candidate into a position. It is not acceptable to submit a variance after hiring has
already occurred. If there are questions as to whether someone meets the
qualifications required in licensing rules, the facility can clarify with their assigned
DCWL Consultant prior to hire. CPA rules should not be considered during the
hiring process as these are not CPA staff.
• Any staff that are rehired after leaving the agency or transfer from another
Bethany program to this facility must meet the requirements of Rule 400.1113.
• On 3/26/24, Consultant provided the Quality Assurance Coordinator information
surrounding central registry background checks. Information included the
differences between the CWL-4624 & CWL-1929, initial/annual requirements,
submission timeframes, CPS history review FAQ document, and Communication
Issuance 23-031 (Children’s Protective History Review for Employment).

V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Typed report dates on some youth reports reflected 2023, but the reports were
signed 2024. Please make sure the typed report dates are correct prior to
approval.
• Staff are not allowed to utilize any CPI physical management skills until they are
fully trained. Consultation was offered that the facility updates their policy to
outline which staff are required to be trained in CPI, and when new hire staff will
obtain CPI training in a timely manner.
• Training records for staff do not reflect all training completed, which causes
confusion when auditing employee records. Please ensure consistency and
proper maintenance to training records.
• It is essential there be a checks and balances for new hire trainings to ensure
timely completion on Cornerstone or the "completion date" will not reflect the
correct information for the audit.
• Rule 400.4115 First Aid/CPR certification requires at least one staff on duty with
current First Aid/CPR certification. In reviewing personnel files many staff did not
have current First Aid/CPR certification. The agency needs to be mindful of
which staff have certification to ensure they are available for the youth onsite and
offsite.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There was 1 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. The facility had one staff member substantiated for maltreatment during the
period of review. This occurred as a result of SIR #2023C0000686 dated 10/16/23;
CAP approved 11/22/23. The staff member was placed on administrative leave on
8/15/23 and was ultimately terminated from employment based on the findings of
the investigation.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The 2023 Interim inspection resulted in six violations related to 400.4113(1)(f)(ii)
criminal history checks, 400.4113(1)(i) central registry checks, 400.4127(4)
observation checks, 400.4506(1) fire drills, 400.4167(1) case record maintenance
and ACT 116 722.120(c) falsification. The CAP was approved on 5/25/23. The
facility demonstrated improved compliance in all of these areas except for
400.4113(1)(i) central registry checks and 400.4167(1) case record maintenance.
It should be noted the facility did not meet compliance with Rule 400.4113(1)(i)
during the 2022 Renewal Audit either. Chief Administrator (CA) noted the

background check information survey they have potential new hires complete has
significantly improved the facility’s compliance with conducting background checks
on all previous names and aliases of the candidate. CA noted despite the facility
completing the central registry checks, delays ensue while awaiting approval from
the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) before new hires can commence work,
which causes the central registry checks to be over 30 days old by the time the
employee is officially hired. CA noted to rectify this, they have initiated new
procedures effective January 2024. These procedures include the inclusion of the
expected start date of the employee in the staff’s new hire checklist, submitting a
CWL-1929 for processing if the CWL-4624 is over 30 days old, and a second-tier
review system where the Quality Assirance coordinator examines the file of all new
hires prior to their start date to ensure compliance.
SIR 2023C0000686 dated 10/16/23 had violations for Rule 400.4112(4)(a)
regarding staff's ability to perform the duties assigned and 400.4109(1)(c)
regarding the facility's program statement/policies. The facility has demonstrated
compliance with the CAP during quarterly CAP reviews.
Financial Overview
The facility’s 12-month budget and December 2022 financial audit were reviewed.
There were no financial concerns noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted staff recruitment and retention has been the
greatest challenge and impediment to licensing compliance. CA noted the CAPs
implemented over the reporting period resulted in a deeper awareness and
understanding by staff of why the “line of sight” requirement for youth supervision
is necessary, and how it protects staff and youth. CA noted shift logs were
redesigned to include location of outings and identify staff and youth participating.
There were also changes to the outings policy and staff to youth ratio has
increased where deemed necessary. In addition, GPS tracking and supervisor
review/approval of outings was instituted. CA reported the new policy created to
address the hiring of former clients includes a screening tool, which has been
helpful to make decisions during the hiring process. CA reported the facility
continues to work to stabilize staffing, increase longevity of staffing and holding
staff more accountable for licensing rules. CA noted bi-weekly team meetings and
monthly direct care staff meetings will continue to occur throughout the year. In
addition, program management and leadership staff will meet regularly to ensure
compliance with all rules/requirements and make changes to internal practices as
necessary.

Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff feel the last year has led to a lot of changes due to another facility occupying
the third floor of Bridgeway for the last year. As a result, the second and third floor
teams have had increased communication and consistency. Staff feel everyone is
very caring, empathetic, and compassionate towards the youth they serve. Staff
feel the new leadership team has created an environment where everyone
demonstrates they’re open to feedback and suggestions. Staff feel the team is
very solution focused. Staff feel supported in their roles and feel leadership does a
great job in explaining how changes at the facility affect everyone’s individual
roles. Staff feel changes in policies and procedures are well communicated in
TEAMS and during bi-weekly staff meetings. One staff noted the facility needs to
improve training and have a more structured new-hire training. The staff member
reported it’s being worked on, but it seems to be tough to find time to develop and
implement it.
Youth reported there was nothing they disliked about the facility. Youth reported
staff treat them well, they get enough food, they like the food, they feel safe and
there is nothing they would change.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility occurred on 3/11/24. The only concern noted was the
medication cart being unlocked, but facility staff locked it when Consultant was
present.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
